title: The Best of 2025: My Favorite Reads of the Year (with Awards)
SPFBO Champion Reviews and My Rankings of the Ten Past Champions
description:
Which of the past SPFBO champions will be the champion of champions? Here are my last three reviews and my rankings for all ten! 
All of my SPFBO-related videos can be found in the "SPFBO" playlist on my channel.

title: Where the Channel Will Go and What I‚Äôll Read in 2026
Spoiler-free Review and Discussion of Titus Groan (Gormenghast Book 1) by Mervyn Peake, with Jay
description: Jay from @AContemplativeReader1 joins me to discuss Titus Groan, first of the Gormenghast books. We begin with a spoiler-free review and then delve into the gothic murk of Gormenghast castle!

title: Guy Gavriel Kay's The Summer Tree (Fionavar 1), with Evan and P.L.
description: It's the GGGKR!!! The Great Guy Gavriel Kay Read! Joined by P.L. Stuart (@plstuartthedrownedkingdomsaga), Evan from The Nerdwriter (@Nerdwriter1) and I continue on our journey through the published novels of Guy Gavriel Gay as we go back to his first, The Summer Tree (Book 1 of The Fionavar Tapestry).

title: English Professor‚Äôs Thoughts on Act I of Wano (One Piece)
description: I have finished Act I of Wano in Oda Sensei's One Piece, and I am eager to share my thoughts! While this is not meant to be a comprehensive breakdown of the many allusions and themes woven into the tale, I give my impressions and try to convey a sense of my appreciation for the rich storytelling as well as the characters' development. You can find all my One Piece videos in the "One Piece" playlist on my channel.

title: Steven Erikson's No Life Forsaken (No Spoilers), with A Critical Dragon
description:
Steering clear of spoilers, A.P. Canavan (aka Professor Fireballs) from @ACriticalDragon and I discuss Steven Erikson's No Life Forsaken, the book following The God Is Not Willing in The Witness Series. 
The spoiler-filled discussion will soon be out over at A Critical Dragon!

title: The Weeks That Were: Book News, Channel Updates, and More!
The Way of Edan in Italian! A Discussion on Translation with Abel Montero
description:
Author and translator Abel Montero joins me to discuss his Italian translation of The Way of Edan, and the conversation includes some observations about the joys and tribulations of translating as well as some fun insights into the nature of language and fantasy prose. 
Check out Abel's YouTube channel: @bookswithabel (Abel Montero)

title: Excellent Fantasy Recommendations: Ranking 4 of the 10 SPFBO Champions!
description: For the latest on SPFBO, check out Mark Lawrence‚Äôs blog and the Facebook for SPFBO. For more videos on self-published fantasy from me, see the ‚ÄúSPFBO‚Äù playlist on my channel.

description:
Nikhil from @Shelf-Esteem joins me to discuss Memory, Sorrow, and Thorn by Tad Williams! We begin with our spoiler-free assessments of the series and then dive into spoilers for all three (four?) books. We will be continuing in January of 2026 with the sequel series in Osten Ard!
Nikhil's music channel: @NikhilKoparkarmusic

title: Myth, Dream, Magic, and Fantasy: A Discussion with Dr. Erik Goodwyn from The Imaginarium
description:
Dr. Erik Goodwyn from @theimaginarium joins me to discuss the fascinating connections between myth, dreams, and magic, all of which inform fantasy tales. 
Dr. Goodwyn's fantasy novel King of the Forgotten Darkness on Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/King-Forgotten-Darkness-Ravens-Fantasy/dp/180341765X

title: Why Literary Fantasy Is Worth Writing (And Reading!): The Way of Unity with Sarah Balstrup
description:
Given the state of publishing and reading trends, is it worth trying to write literary fantasy? If so, what makes it worth it? What sort of audience can an author expect after crafting a boundary-pushing fantasy with complex prose and deep engagement with themes? In this video, I chat with Sarah Balstrup, author of The Way of Unity, about these questions and also discuss her book with her.
The Way of Unity on Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/Way-Unity-Velspar-Elegies/dp/0645474703
Sarah Balstrup‚Äôs books on Big Cartel: https://sarahkbalstrup.bigcartel.com/

description: Evan from @Nerdwriter1 joins me to discuss Guy Gavriel Kay's Tigana. We begin with a non-spoiler assessment that touches on the themes of the story and then dive into spoilers for the book.

description: In the eighty-second unbelievable episode of Dear Dr. Fantasy, I get to chat with Silvia from @libraryunbounded! We discuss loads of great books and share insights from what we've learned by having channels within a bookish community.

description:
Adam Bassett, author of An Author's Guide to Setting Design: Worldbuilding & Cartography, and Jack Shepherd, fantasy cartographer, join me to discuss the role of worldbuilding and maps in fantasy literature. 
Kickstarter for An Author's Guide to Setting Design: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/adamcbassett/an-authors-guide-to-setting-design

title: The Weeks That Were: Book News, Channel Updates, and More

description:
Indie authors have several choices when it comes to publishing, and kickstarters are becoming an increasingly popular way to pull it off. S.A. Klopfenstein joins me to share insights on how he ran a successful kickstarter for The Children of the Gods, book one of the Age of Fire series, which we also discuss in the last part of the video (no spoilers).
Kickstarter for Children of the Gods: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/saklopfenstein/children-of-the-gods-special-release-edition-hardcover

title: The Structure and Themes of Malazan: with NerdWriter1 and A Critical Dragon (spoilers for MBOTF)
description: Evan from @Nerdwriter1 and THE NEMESIS himself, @ACriticalDragon, join me to discuss how the structure and the themes of Steven Erikson's The Malazan Book of The Fallen intertwine and support each other. How does the ending of The Crippled God recontextualize the entire series? Why did Erikson refer to Toll the Hounds as the cipher for the series? Just why is Professor Fireballs the truest, most nefarious (nefariousest?) Nemesis ever? These questions and more shall be explored. Come for the witty banter, stay for the fireballs! Spoilers for The Malazan Book of the Fallen.

After we explain the giveaway, there's a non-spoiler discussion of Ascendant followed by a spoiler-filled chat of the same.

description: With reference to the increasing evidence that leaning on AI tools can be detrimental to critical thinking skills and to studies that suggest that using AI as a substitute for human creativity leads to less fulfillment, @ACriticalDragon and I discuss our thoughts on the use of AI within academic and creative realms.

title: Rapid Reviews of Four SPFBOX Finalists + a New Favorite!
Crafting Book Covers that Tell the Story: A Conversation with Artist Don Maitz
description:
Winner of two Hugo Awards for Best Professional Artist and other prestigious honors, renowned artist Don Maitz offers a masterclass on how covers can convey the essence of the stories they grace. His insights shed light not only on the various elements that every artist must consider, but also make clear why the human experience is essential to craft cover art that is true to the spirit of stories.
Don Maitz's article "How to Tell a Book by Its Cover": https://www.paravia.com/DonMaitz/about/howToTell.php
Don Maitz's website (including a gallery): https://www.paravia.com/DonMaitz/

title: Music and Storytelling: a discussion with Hollywood composer Nikhil Koparkar
description:
With musical credits to his name such as working for television series like The Wheel of Time and His Dark Materials, Nikhil Koparkar has also composed the recently released theme song for The Edan Trilogy, "Blessed be the Eternal." In this video, he and I discuss the role of music in various kinds of storytelling and as a form of storytelling itself. We also delve into the process of composing "Blessed be the Eternal" and what it means to capture the essence of a story in music.
Nikhil's BookTube channel: @Shelf-Esteem 
His music channel: @NikhilKoparkarmusic 
Listen to "Blessed be the Eternal" on Nikhil's channel (with links in the description to purchase the song): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FpO50rHlijM

title: Blessed Be The Eternal: The Edan Trilogy Theme Song, composed by Nikhil Koparkar with art from TBB
description:
Composed by Nikhil Koparkar (@NikhilKoparkarmusic and @Shelf-Esteem), "Blessed Be The Eternal" is the theme song of The Edan Trilogy. In this video, it accompanies art for the special edition of The Way of Edan by The Broken Binding. Featuring a song of origin, the piece captures the epic sweep and beauty of the story told in The Way of Edan, The Prophet of Edan, and Return to Edan. 
Music composed by Nikhil Koparkar
Cello played by Rohana Chase
Vocals by Nikhil Koparkar
Sound engineering by Todd Collins and students
Sound mixing by Nikhil Koparkar
Link to purchase the special edition of The Way of Edan from The Broken Binding: https://thebrokenbindingsub.com/products/the-way-of-edan-tbb-press-edition
Art direction by @PetrikLeo 
Dust jacket and interior color art by Rene Aigner
Interior black and white art by Peng Lu
Map by Jack Shepherd

title: SPFBOX: Five Semifinalists and ONE FINALIST, with Vaughn, Matt, Abel, Sam, and Brian
description:
Let's celebrate great self-published fantasy! The Self-Published Fantasy Blog Off (SPFBO), the contest founded by author Mark Lawrence to shine a light on self-published fantasy, is in its tenth year, giving us SPFBOX (the "X" being for Roman numeral 10)! My team is one of ten judging teams reading a total of 300 books, with 30 going to each team. Each member of my team read six books and picked one as a semifinalist. My task was to read all five semifinalists from my team and determine which is our team's finalist, which will in turn compete against the other nine finalists to determine the winner of SPFBOX. In this video, I discuss the five semifinalists with my team members before revealing our team's finalist! 
Vaughn Roycroft's blog: https://vaughnroycroftblog.com/
Matt: @geauxreadbooks 
Abel: @bookswithabel 
Sam: @SamHarrison2099 
Brian: @BrianBell7

title: What I‚Äôve Learned About Self-Publishing: Some Thoughts and Tips for Authors and the Curious
description:
This video is a broad overview of some of the things to know about self-publishing books. There are detailed videos on YouTube about each of the topics I discuss. 
Here are the topics I cover:
Introduction: 0:01-2:08
Two most important takeaways: 2:09-5:29
Benefits to self-publishing: 5:30-7:26
Overview of topics: 7:27-8:15
Hiring an editor: 8:16-12:40
Hiring an artist and cover designer: 12:41-14:31
Formatting the interior of your book: 14:32-15:59
Deciding on a publishing platform: 16:00-21:12
Special editions: 21:13-22:29
Audiobooks: 22:30-25:18
Marketing (Hiring a marketer, social media, advertising, contests, getting reviews, dealing with reviews): 25:19-40:55

title: How to Analyze Stories: Understanding Tone, Style, Irony, Genre, and Audience with A.P. Canavan
description:
Of use to readers, reviewers, and authors, this video (part seven of a series) focuses on tone, style, irony, genre, and audience as crucial aspects of storytelling. In this series, A.P. Canavan (@ACriticalDragon) and I share what we‚Äôve learned about analyzing stories over the years. During the series, we will cover various topics, including story versus plot, narrative perspective, characters, setting and world building, symbols, tone and style, and themes. It is our hope that the tools and techniques we discuss will add enjoyment to people‚Äôs storytelling journeys.
I am collecting all the videos in the "How to Analyze Stories" playlist on my channel.

title: Evocations of Edan: Original Cello Music by Rohana Chase (my daughter)
description:
The Way of Edan, book one of The Edan Trilogy, was published one year ago, so here is music to commemorate the occasion. Sit back and let yourself ease into this one, which is, like The Edan Trilogy, a slow build to an emotional climax. The recording of this original piece by Rohana Chase (my daughter) is from a live and improvised performance with a cello, a loop pedal, and a delay pedal. For me, it especially evokes the ending of Return to Edan, the third and final book. 
Rohana's Music Instagram: @r.o.h.a.n.a
To mark the one year anniversary of The Way of Edan, all three ebooks of the trilogy are on sale for $0.99 at Amazon from March 21 until March 25.

title: The Best of Fantasy: TOP TEN Authors Who AWE You with Their WORLD BUILDING
description:
For the sixth installment in my "Best of Fantasy" series, I focus on world building! Through sheer imagination and magic, the authors I mention immerse us in created worlds, taking us on journeys filled with wonder and awe -- and perhaps helping us to see the beauty and wonder in our own world in the process. 
All the videos in this series appear in the "Best of Fantasy" playlist on my channel. They are my attempt to add a little nuance to the top ten format on BookTube and to delve into just what makes us love the stories by our favorite fantasy authors.

title: The Mahabharata: The Greatest Epic and Its Role in Modern Fantasy, with Gourav, Mihir, and Ruthan
description: Author Gourav Mohanty (Sons of Darkness), critic Mihir Wanchoo (Fantasy Book Critic), and MalazTuber extraordinaire @RuthanBadd join me to discuss The Mahabharata, arguably the greatest epic of all time and a tremendously important cultural influence, and its role in modern fantasy in South Asia and beyond.

description:
Part four of my series of top ten videos on fantasy authors focuses on prose! Which authors stop you in your tracks with a beautifully phrased sentence? Which ones bring a landscape to life with their gorgeous words? Which ones immerse you in their vivid worlds and capture life on the page?
I attempt to answer these questions, and I would love to hear your answers too. 
The other videos in this series appear in the "Best of Fantasy" playlist on my channel.

title: The Best of Fantasy: TOP TEN Authors Who Make You LAUGH
description:
With apologies to Mark Lawrence for referring to his first trilogy as ‚ÄúBroken Earth‚Äù . . . thrice. I do know the difference between ‚ÄúEmpire‚Äù and ‚ÄúEarth‚Äù on most days. 
This video is part of a series where I get a little more nuanced with the top ten format we usually see on BookTube. In doing so, I hope to generate a conversation about the fantasy books that make us think, cry, laugh, and so much more.

title: The Best of Fantasy: TOP TEN Authors Who Make You CRY
description:
Which fantasy authors cause shortages of tissues? Which wring tears from your eyes? Which rip out your heart, throw it on the floor, and stomp it to a bloody pulp? The ones we love! Here are my top ten fantasy authors who can make you cry through death, triumph, companionship, suffering, reunion, vulnerability, and various other means. 
This video is part two of a series in which I am counting down my top ten fantasy authors according to various measures, such as those who make us think, cry, laugh, etc.

title: Transcendence and The Bhagavad Gita: an interview with translator William S. Whorton
description:
What is the difference between morality and duty? How does transcendence of the self lead to liberation? How do we conduct ourselves on the battlefield of the world? What can we learn from The Bhagavad Gita? We discuss these questions and more in this interview with William S. Whorton, co-translator of The Bhagavad Gita, a recent publication by @UppsalaBooks. 
Website of Uppsala Books: https://uppsalabooks.com/
The Bhagavad Gita on Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/Bhagavad-Gita-Teachings-Battlefield-Life/dp/1961361043/ref=sr_1_1?crid=3DMTZ1E36UP2S&keywords=bhagavad+gita+uppsala+books&qid=1704297283&sprefix=%2Caps%2C109&sr=8-1

title: Another SPFBO Semifinalist! Plus, five other great self-published fantasies!
description: I have selected another of my semifinalists from my batch of SPFBO books. As one of the judges for SPFBO, I have thirty books to choose from. title: Discussion with Tom Shippey on his Beowulf Translation
description:
I had the incredible opportunity to chat with Tom Shippey, distinguished medievalist and Tolkien scholar, about his new translation of Beowulf, edited by Leonard Neidorf. We discuss Tolkien‚Äôs relationship with the Old English poem as well as themes from it and some of the linguistic choices that Shippey made as a translator. 
YouTube channel for Uppsala Books: @UppsalaBooks
Tom Shippey's website: https://tomshippey.com/
Uppsala Books website: https://uppsalabooks.com/

title: Dear Dr. Fantasy: episode 45, with Claudia Iovanovici
description: In the forty-fifth fabulous episode of Dear Dr. Fantasy, we get philosophical as I chat with Claudia from@claudiaiovanovici7569! Claudia is well known in the Malazan community for her excellent interviews with Steven Erikson, but she has read other fantasy series too!

description: I'm back from a month-long visit to Nepal! After sharing a few scenes from the beautiful Himalayan country that is a second home for me, I talk about the latest news for The Edan Trilogy, all the books I'm reading and discussing for the channel, and more.

title: Cover Reveal for Return to Edan (Book Three of The Edan Trilogy)
description:
Like the cover for The Way of Edan (book one of The Edan Trilogy) and the cover for The Prophet of Edan (book two), the cover for Return to Edan was influenced by the stained glass windows designed by Edward Burne-Jones, who in turn was inspired by medieval craftsmanship. 

Cover art by Kyra Gregory (@sleepappointment on Instagram).

Cover design by Jack Shepherd (https://tallshepherd.com/ and @TallShepherd on Twitter). 

Music credit: ‚ÄúDayraven‚Äôs Song‚Äù was generously composed and licensed by @Ian Ravnskjold, who holds the copyright. Check out his channel for loads of excellent music and his catalog of licensable compositions. 

Return to Edan will be available September 21, 2023 on Amazon and from online bookstores. You can also purchase the books in The Edan Trilogy from indie bookstores, such as Silverstones.

title: Review of P.L. Stuart‚Äôs A Drowned Kingdom
description:
In A Drowned Kingdom, book one of the seven-book series The Drowned Kingdom Saga, author P.L. Stuart hearkens back to the classical epics while providing a window for his modern readers to explore some heavy themes. In the process, he tells a gripping story with compelling and conflicted characters. 
Check out P.L. Stuart's channel here: @plstuartthedrownedkingdomsaga

title: Discussion of Monster (Perfect Edition Volume 8) with Merphy Napier
description: Merphy and I have nearly solved the case, surpassing even Detective Lunge in our investigatory skills! Well, at least surpassing him in our imaginations . . . Join us as we discuss the eighth volume of the Perfect Edition (originally volumes 15 and 16) of Naoki Urasawa's Monster!

title: SPFBO Semifinalist #1 and Five Other Great Self-Published Fantasies
description:
I have selected one of my five semi-finalists for SPFBO 9! In addition to reviewing the semi-finalist, I also discuss five great self-published fantasies from my batch of thirty. Though the five are not semi-finalists, their authors put a lot of work and love into them, and it shows. 
As I review the next four semi-finalists in four more videos, I will continue to present five other fantasy reads in each of those videos. 
SPFBO: 300 self-published books! 
30 for me (1 of 10 judges/panels)
5 semi-finalists from me
1 finalist from me to complete with the other 9 finalists
1 winner!

title: Dear Dr. Fantasy: episode 44, with Alex from Books with Banks

title: Song of Folcwalda: medieval music by Ravnskjold inspired by The Way of Edan
description:
@Ian Ravnskjold has done it again! Having composed the music for the cover reveal of The Way of Edan, he has now written a medieval-style piece inspired by the Song of Folcwalda, which appears in Chapter 7 of The Way of Edan: A Dawn Attack (pages 114-115 in the paperback). The Song of Folcwalda is in the style of Old English Poetry, meaning it is alliterative, associative, full of kennings, and concerned with elder days as well as courage as a response to life's fleetingness, among other things. Check out Ravnskjold's channel for plenty more medieval music, including Viking, Celtic, tavern style, and more! 

The Lyrics to the Song of Folcwalda:
Fierce was Folcwalda, the flinger of rings,
When he wended his way, he wielded his folk,
To the banks of the broad one, the blue Theodamar.
Over meadows they marched, from the mother of kingdoms,
From the homeland of heroes, the hallowed Ellorlond.
Unbarred he his breasthoard and brandished his spear,
The ranks he rallied, his rede he made known.
Their shields they shook, from sheaths sprang swords,
Bright were the battle-flames, the blades all keen,
When cried out their king, he kindled their wrath:  
‚ÄúListen! Loaned is this life, not long are we here,
Ere death claims his due, in darkness enfolds us.
The rings come to rust, and rest takes the warriors.
The hawk flies not home, the horses are silent.
The ground will eft guard both the gold and the silver.
The sword of the soldier in sorrow abandoned  
Lies shattered in shards, its sheath now empty.
Hushed is the harp, and the hall stands idle. 
Friends are fleeting, family will perish.
Where have they wandered, the ones who came before?
Where linger the lost, the line of our folk?
In the mirk of the mound are a man‚Äôs longest dreams,
E‚Äôen bold ones will bow, barrows will hold them.
But glory is granted ere the ground claims their bones
To the fearless who flee not from fate‚Äôs mighty grip.
Ere death ends his days, man‚Äôs deeds make his name.
Then go forth to win fame, folk of my heart!‚Äù

description:

In addition, we touch on some of our favorite fantasy series, most especially Malazan, but also The Lord of the Rings, First Law, and The Gentleman Bastard Sequence. Other topics come up too, such as reading Harry Potter as a kid versus reading it as a parent with your kids.

Note for anyone interested in reading the Icelandic sagas that inspired Vinland Saga (the Manga): The two sagas together referred to as The Vinland Sagas are The Saga of the Greenlanders and The Saga of Erik the Red.

title: Originality and Inspiration in Fantasy, with A.P. Canavan
description:
In this chat featuring A.P. Canavan (a.k.a. Professor Fireballs, Apto Canavalian, and A.P. Canadil . . . oh, yeah, and @ACriticalDragon) and yours truly, we discuss the concepts of originality and inspiration in storytelling, specifically in fantasy. What is the difference between an homage and plagiarism? Why has originality become so important? Do we really want originality in stories?
Also, credit to @Paul_van_Doleweerd for the photographic evidence (also featured on the thumbnail) of A.P.'s singing prowess!

title: 15K Livestream Celebration!
description: Bring your questions and your comments as we celebrate two big milestones for the channel: surpassing 15K subs and exceeding 1 million views!

We chat about some of our favorite fantasy stories as well as academia, BookTube, and a host of other things.

After reading two poems about his beautiful friends Max and Jenna, I sit down with my friend Simon Howard to talk about dogs and the roles that they play in fantasy literature. "Dogs" featured on the thumbnail: Jenna and Max, Nighteyes, Belladonna, Roach and Bent, and Huan.

The Tale of Amleth from Gesta Danorum by Saxo Grammaticus (source for The Northman and Hamlet)
description:
In this video, I give a brief overview and summary of the tale of Amleth, from Books Three and Four of Gesta Danorum, an early 13th century legendarium and history by the Dane Saxo Grammaticus. It is perhaps most famous for being the source of Shakespeare's Hamlet and, nowadays, the inspiration for the film The Northman (2022).
Channel mentioned: @ACriticalDragon

An introduction and summary of Tolkien's foundational essay "On Fairy-Stories," this video describes concepts he articulated that have had a strong influence on the fantasy genre, including Secondary Worlds, Sub-Creators, Fantasy, Recovery, Escape, Consolation, and Eucatastrophe.

description:
Dr. A.P. Canavan and I read and discuss Steven Erikson's "Song of Dreaming," an epigraph poem from Dust of Dreams, book 9 of The Malazan Book of the Fallen. With connections to themes in Dust of Dreams and the series as a whole, "Song of Dreaming" is a crucial Malazan poem for expressing what lies at the heart of the series.

title: What is good fantasy prose?: a look at Ursula Le Guin‚Äôs ‚ÄúFrom Elfland to Poughkeepsie‚Äù
description: Taking Ursula Le Guin's essay "From Elfland to Poughkeepsie" as a starting point, I explore prose and style in fantasy. Central to the topic is the concept of the tightrope that epic fantasy writers walk between a style that is too archaic and affected and a style that is too contemporary and mundane. By walking that tightrope, writers of fantasy can help bring alive worlds where transformation takes place.

title: Discussion of Steven Erikson's The God Is Not Willing with A.P. Canavan (spoiler free)
description:
Dr. A.P. Canavan (Professor Fireballs) and I have a spoiler-free chat about Steven Erikson's latest book, The God Is Not Willing, book one of the Witness Trilogy. We talk about its place in the Malazan world and about some of its prominent themes, among other things. Our spoiler-filled discussion will appear on A.P.'s channel, @ACriticalDragon. And, to celebrate the release of the book in The United States, we will have a third chat on the book, featuring none other than Steven Erikson! The conversation with Erikson will appear on A.P.'s channel as well. 
For more videos on Erikson's books and some discussions with him that have appeared on my channel, check out the "Erikson" playlist. There is also a wealth of excellent videos with A.P. discussing writing with Erikson on A Critical Dragon.

title: Discussing Fantasy Archetypes with A.P. Canavan: Part 10, The Dark Lord
description:
In part ten of our discussion series on archetypes in fantasy, A.P. Canavan and I delve into portrayals of "The Dark Lord," where they might come from, and what psychological functions they might serve. Stories discussed include Milton's Paradise Lost, Dante's Inferno, The Silmarillion, Lord of the Rings, Wheel of Time, Harry Potter, Broken Empire, the Belgariad, Dragonlance, Malazan Book of the Fallen, The Black Company, and Thomas Covenant. No significant spoilers for any of the series since we discuss nothing more than each particular version of "The Dark Lord." For parts one through nine of the series on various fantasy archetypes, see the playlist "Archetype Discussion Series" on my channel. 
Check out A.P.'s channel, @ACriticalDragon, for more excellent fantasy-related content!

title: Interview with Michael S. Jackson, author of Ringlander: The Path and the Way
description:

We end the video with some spoilers for Ringlander: The Path and the Way as we delve into favorite characters and moments.

description: Continuing our discussion series on fantasy archetypes, A.P. Canavan (Professor Fireballs) and I delve into the functions and portrayals of the Hero, whose shadow is the Villain, and the Everyman, whose shadow is the Follower. Parts 1-6 of the series can be found on a Playlist on my channel, and part 8 will be out soon on A.P.'s channel, @ACriticalDragon! title: Discussion with Steven Erikson on my Old English translation of his poem "Book of the Fallen"
description:
Steering clear of spoilers for the majority of the video, I have a chat with Steven Erikson, author of The Malazan Book of the Fallen, about my Old English translation of his poem "Book of the Fallen," the prefatory poem that begins the series at the opening of Gardens of the Moon. To begin, Steven Erikson reads and comments on his poem, which serves as an epigraph for the series, following which I read and comment on the Old English translation. Toward the end of the video, we discuss the original poem together with MAJOR SPOILERS FOR THE SERIES. 

Channel mentioned: @ACriticalDragon (Dr. A.P. Canavan, a.k.a. Professor Fireballs)

We keep our observations general, but a warning to anyone who might wish to avoid even vague spoilers. No major spoilers, however. 

Part 1 of this series, our discussion of the archetypes of The Sage and the Magician, appears on A.P.'s channel, @ACriticalDragon! Link to the discussion: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UQpC6pHFbnY&t=104s

title: Malazan poem analysis with A.P. Canavan: Ian Esslemont's "Song of the Exiles"
description:
In this video, Dr. A.P. Canavan (Professor Fireballs) and I explore "Song of the Exiles," the epigraph to chapter four of Ian C. Esslemont's Orb, Sceptre, Throne (book four of Novels of the Malazan Empire). We delve into the poem's inspiration, the Old English poem "The Wanderer," and assess how Esslemont successfully "Malazanizes" his spin on the ubi sunt lament, giving us an epigraph that foreshadows much of the novel. Spoiler free for most of the video, but spoilers toward the end. 

For more Malazan and general fantasy content, check out A.P.'s channel @ACriticalDragon!

title: Discussing Old English poems with the Gwynne brothers: Beowulf, Battle of Maldon, Wanderer & more
description:
I had a wonderful time discussing Old English poems with @thebrothersgwynne! We touched on Beowulf, The Battle of Maldon, The Wanderer, The Seafarer, The Wife's Lament, and Wulf and Eadwacer. The poems represent some of the important source material for the fantasy genre, inspiring authors from Tolkien to John Gwynne. In addition, for the true medievalist geeks, I read a few excerpts from the poems in Old English.  
Ed and Will run a fantastic channel, and I enthusiastically urge you to check it out! 

My discussion of Beowulf with @AndySmithMN: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IctX3zCb8CQ&t=3079s

title: Booktube Shoutouts!!!
The Origins and Development of the Fantasy Genre
description:
This video is a brief history of the fantasy genre, from its origins in the 19th century to the development of the diverse genre of today. This history shows that, with its important social critiques and psychological applications, fantasy is most worthy of critical attention and exploration.
Video on classics and ancient tales for fantasy lovers: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GYoenip1BWY

title: Review of V.E. Schwab‚Äôs A Darker Shade of Magic
description: With a brief discussion on the differences between YA fantasy and adult fantasy, this video reviews V.E. Schwab‚Äôs A Darker Shade of Magic, the first book of the Shades of Magic series.

title: Review of Joe Abercrombie‚Äôs A Little Hatred, book 1 of The Age of Madness Trilogy
description:
This video review of Joe Abercrombie‚Äôs first book in The Age of Madness Trilogy, A Little Hatred, praises the book‚Äôs outstanding character work, clever dialogue, action sequences with perspective shifts, and successful fusion of fantasy with 19th century social novel (think Dickens with more sex and violence and rounder characters), among other things. My favorite book of the year so far! 

Link to my review of Abercrombie‚Äôs First Law Trilogy: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZjV-Z-iXUDk

description: This video takes a look at Jim Butcher‚Äôs Storm Front, first book in The Dresden Files. It includes praise for the book‚Äôs parody of crime fiction as it offers a twist on urban fantasy.

title: Review of R.F. Kuang‚Äôs The Poppy War
description: While the integration of supporting characters and the tying together of plot elements are slight weaknesses, R.F. Kuang‚Äôs The Poppy War is a masterful debut novel with a vivid and compelling protagonist as well as some excellent world building and a fascinating magical system.

title: Review of Mark Lawrence‚Äôs Prince of Fools, book one of The Red Queen‚Äôs War Trilogy
description: This video suggests Mark Lawrence‚Äôs brilliant character work as one of several reasons why The Prince of Fools begins The Red Queen‚Äôs War Trilogy in a manner worthy of The Broken Empire Trilogy, Lawrence‚Äôs previous tale set in the same world.

title: Student teaches English professor about gaming and how to play The Witcher III
description: In this video, an English professor learns about storytelling in gaming from his former student, including the notions that video games are the most immersive form of storytelling and are ideal for fantasy quests. In addition, the professor gets a tutorial in playing The Witcher III!

title: A review of Steven Erikson‚Äôs Forge of Darkness
description: In this spoiler-free review of Steven Erikson‚Äôs Forge of Darkness, the first book of The Kharkanas Trilogy, I take a look at the unique brilliance of Erikson‚Äôs storytelling, in particular the difference of perspective in his books. title: Classics, myths, epics, and more for fans of fantasy
description:
This video is full of recommendations for lovers of fantasy for readings among the epics, myths, and ancient tales that sustained the human imagination for thousands of years and established many of the themes and archetypes common in fantasy.
Texts mentioned: The Mahabharata (including the Bhagavad Gita), The Ramayana, The Iliad, The Odyssey, Beowulf, The Poetic Edda, The Prose Edda, The Saga of the Volsungs, The Niebelungenlied, The Mabinogion, Early Irish Myths and Legends, The Lais of Marie de France, Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, The One Thousand and One Nights, A Midsummer Night's Dream, The Tempest, Paradise Lost, The Kalevala.

title: The Oliphant in the Room: Is Fantasy Racist and Sexist?
description: This was a tough one to make, but I made this video for my students, both past and future, and for my daughters, who are readers of fantasy like me.

title: Top ten fantasy stories for adults, including series and standalones

title: Best Fantasy Books: a look at what goes into the best fantasy books of all time
description:
This video, the first for my channel dedicated to fantasy, is an overview of the fantasy genre and some of its most important and enriching elements: the imagination that comes with magic, a keen sense of the past, a strong emphasis on language (including invented languages, the archaic prose often characteristic of fantasy, and language as magic), and frequent use of archetypes that emerge from human experience and resonate with readers today.
